title: Te atua (The God), from the Noa Noa Suite

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of wood-block print in black ink, over a stenciled orange-ink tone block, on cream wove paper (an imitation japanese vellum).

artist_display:
Paul Gauguin (French, 1848-1903)
printed in collaboration with Louis Roy (French, 1862-1907)
medium_display: Wood-block print in black ink, over a stenciled orange-ink tone block, on cream wove paper (an imitation Japanese vellum)
inscriptions: Monogrammed lower left, in image: "P G O"
publication_history:
Art Center in La Jolla (Calif.), Post Impressionists, exh. cat. (Art Center in La Jolla, 1955), n.pag., cat. 43.

Art Institute of Chicago and Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, Gauguin: Paintings, Drawings, Prints, Sculpture, exh. cat. (Art Institute of Chicago, 1959), p. 84, cat. 157.

Columbia, S.C., Museum of Art, Impressionism: An Exhibition Commemorative of the Tenth Anniversary of the Columbia Museum of Art . . . Symbolic of Its Introduction of New Ideas into the World of Today, exh. cat. (Columbia Museum of Art, 1960), n.pag., cat. 32.

Yoshiaki Inui, Kenji Suzuki, and Takeo Uchiyama, Paul Gauguin, exh. cat. (Shimbun, 1969), n.pag., cat. 75.

Pratapaditya Pal and Robert L. Brown, Light of Asia: Buddha Sakyamuni in Asian Art, exh. cat. (Los Angeles County Museum of Art, 1985), p. 247, cat. 129.

Elizabeth Mongan, Eberhard W. Kornfeld, and Harold Joachim, Paul Gauguin: Catalogue Raisonné of His Prints, with assistance of Christine E. Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld, 1988), p. 80, cat. 17.

Naomi Margolis Maurer, The Pursuit of Spiritual Wisdom: The Thought and Art of Vincent van Gogh and Paul Gauguin (Fairleigh Dickinson University Press, 1998), p. 161, cat. 342 (ill.).

Art Institute of Chicago, Intimate Encounters: Paul Gauguin and the South Pacific; The Edward McCormick Blair Collection, exhibition brochure (Art Institute of Chicago, 2003), cat. 24.
exhibition_history:
Art Center in La Jolla (Calif.), Post Impressionists, Aug. 7–Sept. 25, 1955, cat. 43.

The Art Institute of Chicago, "Gauguin: Paintings, Drawings, Prints, Sculpture," February 12-March 29, 1959, p. 84, cat. 157; traveled to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, April 21-May 31, 1959.

Columbia, S.C., Museum of Art, Impressionism: An Exhibition Commemorative of the Tenth Anniversary of the Columbia Museum of Art . . . Symbolic of Its Introduction of New Ideas into the World of Today, Apr. 3–May 8, 1960, cat. 32.

The National Museum of Modern Art, Kyoto, "Paul Gauguin," October 5-November 7, 1969, cat. 75 (ill.); traveled to Grand Magasin Seibu, Tokyo, August 23-September 30, 1969 and Cultural Center of Fukuoka Prefecture, Fukuoka, November 13-December 7, 1969.

Los Angeles Museum of Art, "Light of Asia: Buddha Sakyamuni in Asian Art, " 1984, p. 247, cat. 129, March 4-May 20, 1984; traveled to The Art Institute of Chicago, June 30-August 26, 1984 and the Brooklyn Museum, November 1, 1984-February 10, 1985.

The Art Institute of Chicago, "Intimate Encounters: Paul Gauguin and the South Pacific, The Edward McCormick Blair Collection," September 6, 2003-January 11, 2004.

The Art Institute of Chicago, "Gauguin: Artist as Alchemist",  June 25 - September 10, 2017, pp. 31, 40, 41, 44n6, 58, 63n11, 235, 236, 238, 247-49, 270, cat. 193, cat. by Gloria Groom, et. al., traveled to Paris, Réunion des musées nationaux - Grand Palais, October 9, 2017 - January 21, 2018.
provenance_text: Sold by Kleemann Galleries, New York, to the Art Institute, 1946.

input: Te atua (The God), from the Noa Noa Suite
